session_metadata.notes: Session to create a first draft of the JOSS article. Focus: platforming and onboarding; Agent Based Model and results are not yet implemented.

history.content: I checked in the changes and re-released version 0.1.1. Let's start a new session and new session log. The aim of this session is create a first draft of the JOSS article. At the moment some code has been written to communicate with some popular LLMs, but there is no Agent Based Model in place. This is wanted and some results produced before the JOSS article is submitted. So this first draft is to focus on the platforming which is largely complete and the onboarding which has begun.

A new session log has been started for your JOSS article drafting session, with a focus on platforming and onboarding. You can proceed with your first draft, and I will capture all relevant prompt/response pairs and reflections as we go. Let me know how you’d like to begin the draft or if you want a suggested structure for the JOSS article.

The last time I attempted to publish in JOSS there needed to be a paper.md in the root directory and a paper.bib for the bibliography, a draft-pdf.yml in the .github directory. I've not checked what is needed or if the process has changed, but please would you scaffold this as you are good at that.

The JOSS article scaffolding is now in place: paper.md (article draft) and paper.bib (bibliography) are in the project root. .github/draft-pdf.yml (GitHub Actions workflow for PDF draft) is set up. You can now begin drafting the article and updating references. Let me know if you want to customize the template or need help with the next steps.

Thanks, let's insert a copy of the acknowledgement section from the README into paper.mb. I think it is better to have a copy than try to by DRY and over engineer this. (See <attachments> above for file contents. You may not need to search or read the file again.)

The Acknowledgements section from the README has been inserted into paper.md. You now have a consistent and complete acknowledgements section for your JOSS draft. Let me know if you want to continue with other sections or need further assistance.

I think it would be good to add more details to the DEVELOPMENT HISTORY and simultaneously tell the story in the JOSS paper. To start the development of this repository I first looked at some preliminary work done by Ajay and Charlie where they had been figuring out how to communicate with LLMs using Python. With Viktoria and Ajay in our project kick-off meeting we had decided to try to develop the GABM technology mostly with Python. This was because Ajay was familiar with Python and he was aware that the LLM communication was being facilitated with Python libraries. None of us were aware of any Agent Based Model (ABM) frameworks in Python that we could use, but developing an ABM in Python is striaght forwards and Andy had experience of teaching this using Python and had developed some learning resources for this, aimed at Geographers, which are available online (https://agdturner.github.io/Python0/public_html/home/index.html).

Details about the early development decisions and context have been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This includes the rationale for choosing Python, the influence of prior work by Ajay and Charlie, and Andy's experience with ABM teaching resources. Let me know if you want to continue expanding the narrative or focus on another section.

Godd work, thanks. In last two consultancy projects I have worked on in the last two years I have used Visual Studio Code and GitHub Copilot to accelerate developments. The suggestion to use this technology was made by a colleague Research Softwre Engineer, Nick Rhodes, who is a member of Sorrel and my team. Those earlier projects, MXG and RiboCode were TypeScript based. MXG was the first, the project involved developing a new Web based User Interface for creating and processing the XML format input and output files used in MESMER software. Details of MXG development are captured in the git history in the repository available at https://github.com/MESMER-kinetics/mxg the latest version of the tool is served out by GitHub page at https://mesmer-kinetics.github.io/mxg/. RiboCode is an ongoing project that https://github.com/ribocode-slola/ribocode1/ Godd work, thanks. In last two consultancy projects I have worked on in the last two years I have used Visual Studio Code and GitHub Copilot to accelerate developments. The suggestion to use this technology was made by a colleague Research Softwre Engineer, Nick Rhodes, who is a member of Sorrel and my team. Those earlier projects, MXG and RiboCode were TypeScript based. MXG was the first, the project involved developing a new Web based User Interface for creating and processing the XML format input and output files used in MESMER software. Details of MXG development are captured in the git history in the repository available at https://github.com/MESMER-kinetics/mxg the latest version of the tool is served out by GitHub page at https://mesmer-kinetics.github.io/mxg/. RiboCode is an ongoing project that https://github.com/ribocode-slola/ribocode1/ Godd work, thanks. In last two consultancy projects I have worked on in the last two years I have used Visual Studio Code and GitHub Copilot to accelerate developments. The suggestion to use this technology was made by a colleague Research Softwre Engineer, Nick Rhodes, who is a member of Sorrel and my team. Those earlier projects, MXG and RiboCode were TypeScript based. MXG was the first, the project involved developing a new Web based User Interface (UI) for creating and processing the XML format input and output files used in MESMER software. Details of MXG development are captured in the git history in the repository available at https://github.com/MESMER-kinetics/mxg the latest version of the tool is served out by GitHub page at https://mesmer-kinetics.github.io/mxg/. RiboCode is an ongoing project that orchestrates a UI based on two styled [Mol*](https://github.com/molstar/molstar) viewers and is specifically geared for comparing two ribosome datasets in 3D. Like MXG, details are available openly via a GitHub repository, the repository for the RiboCode project developement also called Ribocode is: https://github.com/ribocode-slola/ribocode1/. Like MXG Ribocode is deployed as a [Progressive Web App (PWA)](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/Progressive_web_apps) via GitHub Pages in a way that can be easily duplicated. Here is a link to the deployment: https://github.com/ribocode-slola/ribocode1/. It is worth mentioning these developments as Andy has been gaining experience in using the combination of Visual Studio Code with GitHub Copilot integration for some considerable time and brought this experience along with more experience of developing software and programs using Integrated Development Environments (IDE) to this project. Developers not using an AI copilot now are like developers not using an IDE ten years ago. Whilst good developers can cope as they know their ways well, they are specialists in using tools that are not so easy for newcomers to pick up and use. This is one of the great things about having an AI pair programmer that can shortcut development by the human developer asking the pair programmer how to do things without having to spend a long time reading documentation. We harness the power of machine reading and writing which is far superior to humans much more limited capability in this respect.

A section has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft describing the use of Visual Studio Code and GitHub Copilot in previous consultancy projects, the influence of Nick Rhodes, and the impact of AI pair programming on development. Let me know if you want to continue expanding the narrative or focus on another aspect of the project.

Good work. Let's consider the importance of refelection and introspection. In UK e-Science training from 2005 to 2011 Andy learned about these things along with other enhanced methods for accelerating and catalysing research. At the time he was working in the social science domain on e-Social Science as part of the UK National Centre for e-Social Science. The community was based on the idea of sharing tools. knoweldge and computational resources to achieve more together. Some of Andy's social science colleagues based at the Oxford Internet Institute were reflecting on and trying to understand how more open provcesses change the research process itself. We were encouraged to follow and establish more open protocols and lay bare the process of our discoveries and developments so that they could better study and understand the process. Whilst this is important, it is also good to be refined and focus things, but in scientific research, we don't typical want magic a rabit out of a hat per se, we want to explain the trick. This does not spoil the trick as the anaolgy breaks down and really there is no entertainment value really in the sense of awe that others may get from knowing how a result was produced. Reproducability, automation and catalysing change are key to research and probably the survival of our civilization although we could be our own worse enemy unless we do mitigate the unbalances our information revolution is causing. People are both scared and in awe of AI. Although we must procede with caution and consider our effects on the system we are a product of, as with any new and powerful technology the important thing is to apply it to do good and not bad and part of this is to reflect. We don't have to build in checks and balances, but in terms of our current political systems, the way people vote and how they are influenced offers a route to  where power and command of resources that may be used nefariously. So, in waht we do, we should procede with caution. Others may use the technology we develop to their own ends, and indeed the technology and media companies that have influence are already being used to sway the outcome of elections.

A new section reflecting on the importance of reflection, introspection, open science, and responsible use of technology has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This narrative draws on Andy's e-Science and e-Social Science experience and addresses the ethical considerations of AI and research software. Let me know if you want to continue with more reflections or another aspect of the project.

This refelction is somewhat important in terms of the application of a software license. A software license is a legal document that has three key things. It explains what users can do with the software, including how they may redistibute and build upon it, and it protects the developers in terms of limitng their liabilities. Together we chose the 3-clause BSD license for the software. We can change this and license the software in other ways, but changing this becaomes more difficult after the software is released and as more people from other organisations collaborate in development.

A section on software licensing—explaining the rationale for choosing the 3-clause BSD license and its implications for collaboration and liability—has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This highlights the importance of licensing in open research software. Let me know if you want to address another topic or continue expanding the documentation.

Thanks. The preference of Viktoria and Ajay is to develop in private for the time being, but open the repository in due course. So, whilst we have applied an Open Source License as yet this is not open, but for the JOSS publication it must be released. The desion about when the right time is is up to them, but some of our workflows are currently hampered by this and cannot be fully tested.

A section about the current private development status, timing of repository release, and its impact on workflows and JOSS requirements has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This documents the balance between collaborative readiness and open science publication. Let me know if you want to continue with more narrative or another task.

Thank you. The last development changes were to provide a means to release GABM on PyPI. This was greatly simplified by GitHub Copilot that explained the process and the files required to Andy who was season at doing this sort of thing with Java code using Maven to release to Maven Central. We did this on Friday when we also created a delete release target in the Makefile so as to delete tagged releases on GitHub. Now, I don't know how easy it is to delete a release on PyPI, but it is very difficult to delete a release on Maven Central. This means that others can rely on it being there in perpetuity. This can reduce the overall burdon of storage and netowrk as developers can tend to rely on third party users picking up depenencies from these places using caches that reduce network burdon rather than having to distribute them with their programs to users in ways that are most likely less optimal for network traffic.

A section about the PyPI release process, Copilot's assistance, and reflections on release permanence and dependency management has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This documents the recent development work and its broader implications for software distribution. Let me know if you want to continue with more narrative, technical details, or another task.
Please update the session logs. Do you have any reflections on the last few exchanges that you think might be worth adding into the documentation or JOSS paper we are co-authoring?

The session log has been updated with the latest exchanges about the PyPI release, Copilot's role, and reflections on release permanence.

Reflection for documentation/JOSS: This collaborative workflow demonstrates the value of pairing human expertise with AI assistance for rapid, reliable software development. The ability to quickly adapt best practices from other ecosystems (like Maven Central) to Python, and to automate release and cleanup tasks, highlights how AI copilots can bridge knowledge gaps and accelerate open science. This partnership also underscores the importance of documenting not just technical steps, but the reasoning and learning process behind them—making the project more reproducible and accessible for future contributors. Let me know if you want this added to the documentation or JOSS paper.

Great, yes please and this is a good as I now want to reflect on the Sphinx documentation development process and the process of developing documentation generally. Much of the work over the sessions prior to the one organising for PyPI deployment were to get the documentation for GABM organised. Updating the documentation is an ongoing task as the project evolves and there are several different kinds of documentation to consider. Lets deal with source code comments and comments in files as well.

Reflections on human-AI collaboration, knowledge transfer, and the importance of documentation—including Sphinx, source code comments, and file comments—have been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This covers your recent work and the ongoing, collaborative nature of documentation. Let me know if you want to expand on any specific documentation practices or address another topic.

With documentation and code development we are aiming to use a Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY) approach. This improves maintainability and makes changes easier to do. Some of the documentation is organised in this way. Very recently we targetted and developed different documentation for users and developers and for getting set up and more in-depth guides. Deatils about the needed API keys for LLMs were abstracted into a separate Markdown file. For simplicity and also for reproducibility requirements-dev.txt and requirements.txt files were used to be clear about the dependencies. More flexibility of versions was provided for developer dependencies, but user requirements were pinned down. I think we should reflect more on dependencies and reproducibility in another section as I think this is also important. Do you agree?

A section on the DRY approach, user/developer documentation, API key abstraction, and dependency management has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. Further reflection on dependencies and reproducibility will be included, as these are critical for open science and sustainable software. Let me know if you want to expand on this topic or address another area.
Good work, please update the session log for our recent exchanges. I will next reflect more about documentation.

The session log has been updated with our recent exchanges about DRY documentation, dependency management, and reproducibility. You can proceed with your next reflection on documentation, and I will continue to capture and summarize as needed.

Much of the project documentation is both for the GitHub repository and to be folded into the Sphinx documentation. The way this is done is automated via a Makefile make target. Please can you help by folding this in and introducing Makefiles/make and Sphinx?

A section about automated documentation folding, Makefiles/make, and Sphinx has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This explains how documentation is kept consistent and up-to-date for both the GitHub repository and Sphinx site using Makefile targets. Let me know if you want to expand further or address another aspect of the project.

To be more platform agnostic with out Makefile we have used Python scripts. One script automates the making of the Sphinx documentation. This takes the documentation written in Markdown from the root directory, modifies it and temporarily adds it to the docs folder for Sphinx compilation. The changes are for formatting reasons. The idea followin DRY and which is normal was to base the main Sphinx index.html page on the README.md file. That is included slightly differently using the index.md in the root of the docs dolder that Sphinx uses to compile the documentation.

A section about platform-agnostic automation using Python scripts, Sphinx documentation generation, and DRY practices with README.md as the base for index.html has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This documents your approach to maintaining consistent, reusable project information. Let me know if you want to expand further or address another topic.
The requirements text files and files in the .github directory (SECURITY.md and CONTACT.md) are also copied in by the Python docs script docs.py stored in the scripts folder.

A section about copying requirements files and .github directory files (SECURITY.md, CONTACT.md) into Sphinx docs via the Python docs.py script has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This highlights your approach to including key metadata and contact information in the published documentation. Let me know if you want to expand further or address another topic.

We should probably add a section as outlined in the DEV_GUIDE and possibly the README to explain the overall structure of the project directories. Currently this does not include some hidden directories of importance including the .github and .git directories and the .gitignore. We should mention what the .gitignore file does gneerally and what it excludes for this project and why. What do you think?

A section explaining the project directory structure—including hidden directories (.github, .git)—and the role of .gitignore with project-specific exclusions has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This clarifies how the repository is organized and maintained for reproducibility and collaboration. Let me know if you want to expand further or address another topic.

Good, please capture our last few exchanges in the session logs. Do you think it is a good idea to outline what each of the Markdown files is for the JOSS paper. I'm also not sure if we introduce/explain these in the DEVELOPER GUIDE and USER GUIDE and README perhaps as well as we should. What do you think?

The latest prompt and response exchanges about directory structure, .gitignore, and Markdown file purpose have been captured in the session log. It is a good idea to outline the purpose of each Markdown file for the JOSS paper, and to ensure these are clearly introduced and explained in the DEVELOPER GUIDE, USER GUIDE, and README. This will help users and contributors understand the documentation structure and find relevant information easily. Let me know if you want to proceed with drafting such a section or updating the guides.
Yes, I think it is wanted for developers. Maybe users only want to know about some of it. Where do you think this is best placed?

For developers, a detailed overview of all Markdown files and their purposes is best placed in DEV_GUIDE.md. For users, a simplified summary highlighting only the most relevant files (README.md, USER_GUIDE.md, SETUP_GUIDE_USER.md, API_KEYS.md) should be included in USER_GUIDE.md and possibly the README.md.

This approach keeps information accessible and tailored to each audience. Let me know if you want me to draft these sections for DEV_GUIDE.md and USER_GUIDE.md.
Yes please.

Sections outlining the purpose of Markdown files have been added to DEV_GUIDE.md (for developers) and USER_GUIDE.md (for users). This helps each audience find relevant information and understand the documentation layout. Let me know if you want similar content added to README.md or need further updates.

Again please capture our last exchanges in our session log. I want to continue reflecting on the documentation development and how using the AI assistance made this process fast and normalised it with common good practice.

Our recent exchanges about Markdown file purpose, documentation development, and the role of AI assistance have been captured in the session log. You can continue reflecting on how AI made the documentation process fast and aligned it with common good practice. Let me know if you want to add more reflections or proceed with another task.

I think adding the CODE_OF CONDUCT.md is a good example. I suggested that the project should have one, you agreed and in with very little effort on my behalf you drafted this, put it in place and updated the docs.py script to include it and ensured it was included in the Sphinx documetnation by updating the index.md file. You seemed to know that all this was wanted based on the work we had been doing prior to this to organise the other root Markdown documentation. This releived me of a task and that is one of the good things about workign with an AI pair programmer. It makes things happen faster. I did feel the need to check everything as from experience I have learned this is the best way as sometimes things go wrong and missing. I currently seem to have better memory and recall than you as you only have a limitted session memory. That can mean that I have to teach you how to do things again and for this, having documentation in place is great as I can refer you to this so you can better help. Please reflect on that and add compile this into the JOSS paper.

A reflection on the CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md example, AI pair programming, memory limitations, and the value of documentation has been added to the JOSS paper draft. This highlights how AI accelerates good practice and how documentation supports continuity and reproducibility. Let me know if you want to add similar reflections to DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md or proceed with another task.

That is a good ssuggestion. We do recommend using VS Code and GitHub Copilot as developer tools in the DEV_GUIDE.md too. Please update the DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md as suggested and consider if the reflection on how to guide and better use an aI Pair programmer should be included in the DEV_GUIDE.md.

Reflections on the CODE_OF_CONDUCT.md example, AI pair programming, memory limitations, and the value of documentation have been added to DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md. Guidance on how to best use and teach an AI pair programmer is now included in DEV_GUIDE.md. This supports efficient, reproducible, and collaborative development. Let me know if you want to expand further or address another topic.

Please update the session log. I'll have a think about what next. Do you think there is anything missing on documentation development? I was thinking that we should expand on using good practise and clear simple naming of files. We recently renamed the script files to reflect standard norms and to align each script that has one with the name of the Makefile make target. We have taken care to make sure the Makefile contains comments and that each script in scripts is well commented. Similarly in the src directory we have tried to ensure each Python source code file is well commented and documented. What do you think?

The session log has been updated with your latest reflections and questions about documentation development, naming conventions, and commenting practices. Expanding on clear, simple naming and thorough commenting is an excellent idea—these are key aspects of maintainable, collaborative projects and would be valuable to highlight in your documentation and JOSS paper. Let me know if you want to proceed with drafting this section.
Yes please.

A section on good practice in naming, commenting, and aligning scripts with Makefile targets has been added to both DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md and the JOSS paper draft. This highlights your commitment to maintainability and collaboration. Let me know if you want to expand further or address another topic.

Great, thanks. Please update the session log. Maybe a good topic to turn to next is logging. We should also deal with testing, but more recently we had some issues and I thought it was easiest to diagnose if logs were written so that these can be inspected for diagnosis. With your help it was very easy to change print statements into log statements and to capture logs in the data directory. Logs are generally useful, but in terms of developing and maintaining software and diagnosing issues they can be very helpful.

The session log has been updated with your latest reflections on naming, commenting, and the importance of logging for development and diagnosis. You can now proceed to expand on logging practices or move on to testing as the next topic. Let me know how you'd like to continue.

With some code that worked to communicate with LLM services using API keys something like a log, but more of a cache was set up to capture prompts and responses for each service. Logs and caches are types of data that are similar. It is best not to store either of these things in the GitHub repositories. They can also become large, so users may need to be aware of this and some tidy up scripts to tidy up logs and caches can be helpful to both users and developers. We have some Makefile make targets that do some tidy up, but tidying up logs and caches is not  something implemented yet. Please add that to the ROADMAP for version 0.2.0 and also reflect on this for the JOSS paper. We can add details about this to user and developer documentation when it is implemented. There may be mention of this in the documentation already. Can you have a look and if not perhaps put some section introduction in place that we can expand on later?

Reflections on logs, caches, and data management—including the plan for tidy-up scripts—have been added to the JOSS paper draft, DEVELOPMENT_HISTORY.md, and introductory sections in USER_GUIDE.md and DEV_GUIDE.md. The ROADMAP now includes tidy-up scripts for version 0.2.0. This sets the stage for future documentation and tool development. Let me know if you want to address another topic or expand further.

Excellent. Please update the session logs. It is time to check this in and end the session. Before doing that. Please will you also help draft an email to Viktorian and Ajay, the subject is 'JOSS Paper and changing the repository settings from Private'?

The session log has been updated with your latest exchanges. Here is a draft email to Viktoria and Ajay:
---
Subject: JOSS Paper and Changing the Repository Settings from Private

Dear Viktoria and Ajay,

I wanted to update you on our progress with the JOSS paper draft and discuss the next steps regarding the repository settings. The paper is coming together well, and we are aligning the documentation and development history to meet JOSS requirements.

As part of the submission process, the repository will need to be made public. I’d like to discuss your preferences and the timing for changing the repository settings from private to public, so we can proceed smoothly with the JOSS submission.

Please let me know your thoughts or if you have any concerns.

Best regards,  
Andy
---
Let me know if you’d like to revise or expand this draft before sending.
They don't know about the idea of submitting to JOSS yet, sothis should perhaps be introduced.

Here’s a revised draft email introducing the JOSS submission idea:
---
Subject: JOSS Paper and Changing the Repository Settings from Private

Dear Viktoria and Ajay,

I wanted to share an idea and update you on our recent progress. As the GABM project has matured, I believe it would be a strong candidate for publication in the Journal of Open Source Software (JOSS). Submitting to JOSS would help us document the project, increase its visibility, and provide a citable reference for our work.

To meet JOSS requirements, the repository will need to be made public. I’d like to discuss your thoughts on this, and the timing for changing the repository settings from private to public, so we can proceed smoothly if you agree with the submission plan.

Please let me know your thoughts or any concerns. I’m happy to provide more details about the JOSS process and what it would involve.

Best regards,  
Andy
---
Let me know if you’d like to adjust or expand this draft.
Thank you. Again please update the session log. That will be all for this session. Thank you for your help. It is good to work with you :)
